body.content:
To get started, we need a quick overview on the earthquake data in the database.

Select the first 10 rows from the earthquakes table.

name: Magnitude Range

body.content: What is the magnitude range of the earthquakes stored in the database? Select the strongest and weakest earthquake magnitude.

solution.content: SELECT min(magnitude) AS weakest, max(magnitude) as strongest FROM earthquakes

hint: You need to aggregate on the same attribute twice using two different functions.

name: Earthquake depths

body.content:
Produce an overview on available depth data for earthquakes. Select four rows from earthquakes. Each record should have a description and value attribute. Use the UNION statement to merge the records together. Query the following information:

  • deepest - the largest depth at which an earthquake was recorded.
  • mean - the average depth at which earthquakes occur
  • total - the total amount of records
  • 'with depth' - the total amount of records with a depth of more than 0

solution.content:
SELECT 'deepest' AS description, max(depth) AS value FROM earthquakes
UNION
SELECT 'mean' AS description, avg(depth) AS value FROM earthquakes
UNION
SELECT 'total' AS description, count(*) AS value FROM earthquakes
UNION
SELECT 'with depth' AS description, count(*) AS value FROM earthquakes WHERE depth > 0

hint: Build each of the four queries separately and union them at the end. In this exercise we do not filter for the earthquake type.

body.content:
Is there a trend over time?

I am not a seismologist, but I would not expect any natural or antropogene explanation for increasing numbers. The increase itself is nevertheless expected, as the measuring equippment should have become more sensitve in the past 70 years.

Does the number of earthquakes per year change? Reduce the earthquakes table to an yearly count time series. Name the attributes year and conut and order them ascending.

You can use the plotting tab to quickly plot the result.

solution.content:
SELECT date_part('year', datum) AS year, count(*) FROM earthquakes
GROUP BY year
ORDERBY BY year ASC

name: Shaky day

body.content: Which is the day at which most earthquakes were observed? Select their count, datum and the magnitudes themselves as an array of double pricision[]. Check out the correct casting function in the Postgres documentation.

solution.content:
SELECT datum, count(*), array_agg(magnitude) AS magnitudes FROM earthquakes
GROUP BY date_trunc('day', datum), datum
ORDER BY count DESC
LIMIT 1

hint: To turn the single magnitudes into an array of magnitudes, you need a cast function: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/functions-aggregate.html.

body.content: There is a lookup table about different types of earthquakes called earthquake_types. Check out the table and reduce the earthquakes to the type name followed by the amount of data associated to that type.

solution.content:
SELECT t.name, count(*) as amount FROM earthquakes e
JOIN earthquake_types t ON e.type_id=t.type_id
GROUP BY t.name

body.content: To learn a bit more about the earthquake types, it would be interesing, if nuclear explosions are stronger than earthquakes. We cannot compare the number directly (by i.e. averaging) as the sample sizes are very different. Rank the nuclear explosions by the caused magnitude and calculate the ratio of nuclear explosions that are within the 2300 (~10%) strongest events. Call that attribute strong_ratio

solution.content:
WITH r AS (
	SELECT CASE WHEN ranks < 2300 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END AS in_upper_10, type_id 
	FROM
	(
		SELECT rank() OVER (ORDER BY magnitude DESC) AS ranks, type_id 
		FROM earthquakes
	) t
	WHERE type_id=3
)
SELECT 
	sum(r.in_upper_10)::real / count(r.in_upper_10)::real as strong_ratio
FROM r

body.content: Find the datum, magnitude and wkt of the 100 strongest earthquakes. The wkt should be a WKT representation of the geom attribute. You can use the Map plotting tool below to learn about the spatial distribution.

solution.content:
SELECT datum, ST_AsEWKT(geom) as wkt, magnitude FROM earthquakes
ORDER BY magnitude DESC
LIMIT 100

body.content: Our main goal is to group and reduce the earthquake dataset to per-country statistics. For this, we can use the World Border Dataset, which the hydenv cli is able to load to the database. To get an overview, load the wkt of the geom attribute along with the name of all datasets.

solution.content: SELECT ST_AsEWKT(geom) as wkt, name FROM world_borders
